physDesc.p: Five pages typewritten in black ink. Mrs. Richard Aldington 44 Mechlenburgh Square London, W.C. England is the typed address given for H. D. in the top left corner of the first page. Unsigned.

editorialDecl.p: This letter contains references to the following:

body.p: I am perfectly delighted with this photograph of Richard which your mother sent to me. I think it is the best one of him that I have ever seen. Personally, I like him better without the beard which appeared after I left, and which showed in the only other photograph of him which I had. He looks well, which is good to see, and brings him up before me so vividly that it makes me more homesick than ever.

I have not heard from you for ages. I rather thought that I should get a letter after you got my article, and that you got it I know, for Lawrence wrote me that you had sent it to him. Perhaps your letter went down, but I am tormented with the fact that perhaps you did not like the article, and hence your silence. That would really grieve me very much, so that I hope it is merely my hyper-sensitive desire to get a little on paper of my great admiration for Richard’s work, I was so sorry not to be able to include him in my book that I specially wanted you to like this article. But I try to console myself by feeling that probably your letter is sitting at the bottom of the broad Atlantic.

Here are our half-yearly royalties: SALES 34 Imagist Poets, 1915 at .36-1/4 12.33 24 " " 1916 at .36-1/4 8.70 71 " " 1917 at .36-1/4 25.74 $46.77 $46,77 divided by 6-$7.76 or 1.11.9 They are not, as you see, of a very magnificent figure, but that can hardly be expected. The War has cut into everybody’s sales – everybody who is not writing war books, that is.

As I wrote you last year, I am now letting the Anthologies go slowly, but surely, out of print. I wrote to all of you and asked your advice on the subject, last year and all of you that deigned to reply agreed. I do not remember whether Flint gave his opinion, and I am quite sure that Lawrence never gave his, but the price of reprinting now is so great and the sales so inconsiderable, and the fact that most of the poems in those books have been reprinted in our own various books makes me feel that we had better let them lapse. If you have changed your mind since you agreed, let me know, because, of course, I want to be quite fair on the subject. But I do think it is probably better for all of us to have people now forced to buy our individual books rather than getting us this way.

There are now on hand: 4 Copies of "Some Imagist Poets – 1915." 147 " " "Some Imagist Poets – 1916." 94 " " "Some Imagist Poets – 1917." So you see that it will not be a great while before they are unobtainable. Then they will probably be greatly desired by collectors and bought at enormous figures at auctions, and we shall gain nothing thereby. But such is the way of fame!

I wonder if you have come across a little pamphlet on me written by an unknown admirer, Miss Winifred Bryher. I know nothing whatever about the girl; perhaps you do. She is a great admirer of yours, and writes really extremely good poetry. But this pamphlet is the first of her published works, I believe. I judge that she has been very much protected and cared for by Mr. Clement K. Shorter, the editor of "The Sphere", and other gentlemen of good standing, since her pamphlet has been sent not only to all the English newspapers, but to all the American periodicals as well, and I can hardly think that a new writer would have thought of doing this without advice.

Her book has been reviewed most favourably by Mr. Shorter in "The Sphere" and by some one in "The Tatler," and by some one else in the Literary Supplement of the "Times." But it has been fearfully slammed by an oaf named James Douglas in "The Star." The papers here are principally amused that she should consider me unknown, which is flattering as far as it goes.
Seriously, the girl has insight and a good deal of critical faculty, but she expresses herself with such extreme admiration that I am afraid that perhaps her very words cause their own reaction.

I have had a very characteristic letter from Michael Sadler, asking me if it did not embarrass me to have a pamphlet written about me. Perhaps it does a little, considering the terms she uses, but I am very grateful to her just the same. There is still too much misunderstanding for one not to be glad to find such whole-hearted sympathy, and the fact that I have never seen the girl, and know no one whom she knows, shows that it came entirely through the poems.

I wish that I could send you a copy. Unfortunately it is not to be bought on this side of the ocean. It is published by the Eyre & Spottiswoode, and probably your circulating library could produce it if you care to see it.

I feel quite sure that the Ezra crowd will get hold of it and make awful fun of it in "The Egoist," but possibly that will not do a great deal of harm, even if they do. What does Ezra mean in his ultimatum in the last number of "The Little Review"? It sounds almost as if he were going to withdraw from that Paper. It has made not hit on this side of the ocean at all. I do not know what Ezra’s particular crowd may think of it since he undertook so much of the management, but here it is unknown and unconsidered, and James Joyce’s pornographic obscenities have not even caused a ripple of interest outside of Greenwich Village, where, I suppose, they are considered even as the Bible.

Do you remember my writing to you last year telling you what a gratuitous insult William Carlos Williams had thrown at me in a series of letters? Well, by way of making things too funny, here comes a very pleasant note from him in praise of "Appuldurocombe Park," which came out in the August number of "Poetry." Oh, Hilda, things are odd!

You cannot think how hungry and thirsty I am for a sight of you and Richard. So many poets here have gone to the war, and the travelling expenses are now so high, that we meet each other very seldom in this vast country; and as there are none settled here in Boston, with the exception of Conrad Aiken with whom I have a continued and to me quite unintelligible feud, it is lonely in the extreme.

I find, as the war goes on, that it is increasingly difficult to take things out of one’s brain when one never has any stimulus of other poets to put things in. Luckily, I have a good deal to run on, but somehow I feel that if the war does not end soon we shall all be done, all people would be in prison cells.
My health, too, is so precarious and so rotten that it makes all travelling an added burden. However, I do not mean to croak, as I am very much better off than most people.
I sent to Sadler for some copies of "New Paths," and he said that he was sending it to me, but it has not come yet. I am most anxious to see all the things that you have been doing.

I cannot get Richard’s proofs out of Brown. He has asked me to read them for him, but he never sends me any, and whether he is going to get along without my intervention, or whether he is just as usual procrastinating, I do not know.

Your mother says that I had better send my letters to Mechlenburgh Square, as you may not stay in Cornwall very long, so I am sending this there and hope that it will be promptly forwarded. Do tell me how yours and Richard’s work is getting on.
